page.title: 15THE SALE OF CHESTNUT POLES
page.content: Poles which are not to be used by the Cowdray estate are sold at auctions, which take place on the last Tuesday in October and end on 25th March. A poster exists, which advertises the auction at the King's Arms, Henley, in 1838. It is traditional for the workers on the coppice plantations and the buyers to partake of a venison lunch at the last auction of the year, and Lord Cowdray has continued this custom. Beams in old houses, reputedly oaken, are frequently of chestnut wood, which is as durable as the heart of oak, and much more quickly produced than oak.
